msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a 12th century copy, written in Spain, of the Sententiarum of St. Isidore (ca. 560-636), bishop of Seville and one of the Doctors of the Church. The Sententiarum is a collection of theological writings meant to serve as a manual for the clergy. Most of the passages were culled from the works of Gregory the Great and St. Augustine. It is divided into three parts and covers subjects such as creation, the nature of evil, ecclesiastical orders, and the judgment of God.

msItem.title: Isidore of Seville, Sententiarum
msItem.incipit: Su[m]mum bonu[m] D[eu]s e[st]. q[ui]a incommutabilis e[st] et corru[m]pi om[n]ino non potest. [1v]
msItem.explicit: Illi eni[m] deplorandi s[un]t in morte, quos miseros in fernus ex hac uita recipit, no[n] quos celestis aula letificandos concludit [sic]. [fol. 154R]

supportDesc.extent: ii+154+ii; 199 x 146 mm bound to 205 x 162 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.signatures: Signatures throughout, Roman numerals, bottom center verso; signatures towards the end are trimmed fully or partially: 8v, 16v, 24v, 32v, 40v, 48v, 56v, 64v, 72v, 80v, 88v, 104v, 112v, 136v, 152v

layoutDesc.layout: Written area: 157 x 105 mm, prickings visible on some leaves; One column of twenty-one of lines, hard point ruling; two decorated initials; two-, three-, and five-line red initials throughout; chapter numbers and titles in red throughout; marginal notes and corrections in a contemporary hand

decoDesc.decoNote: Decorated initials and rubrication throughout; several manicules

binding.p: 19th-century brown morocco with blind stamped covers by Riviere, gilt edges. S. YSIDORI LIBRI TRES SENTENTIARUM CODEX M. S. IN MEMBRANIS S.AEC. XII stamped in gold on spine.

history.provenance: J. and J. Leighton (booksellers), London; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia, purchased July 28, 1920; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; Printed description from catalog of J. and J. Leighton tipped onto front flyleaf; "Bound by Riviere" stamped in inside front cover
